deliberation: Considered whether the temporal and geographical notices are literal (they are), and whether 'the heavens opened' and 'visions of God' are figurative. Treated 'the heavens opened' (נִפְתְּחוּ הַשָּׁמַיִם) as a conventional metaphor/idiom for revelatory access to the divine realm rather than a literal tearing of the sky.

instances.english_text: the heavens opened
vehicle: the heavens opening like a physical barrier
ground: removal of separation between human and divine realms; sudden access
posture: Ezekiel adopts conventional prophetic idiom for his call experience
instances.explanation: Uses the image of the sky opening as a metaphorical idiom for God granting direct revelatory access.

deliberation: Purely chronological and historical dating formula; no comparisons, anthropomorphisms, or idioms beyond standard prose dating.

Examined 'the word of YHWH came to' and 'the hand of YHWH was upon him.' The former is a standard way of speaking about revelation; the latter clearly attributes a bodily part and physical action to God as a way of speaking about divine power/inspiration.

instances.english_text: And the hand of the LORD came upon him there.
target: God's exertion of power in prophetic inspiration over Ezekiel
vehicle: bodily limb used for grasping and exerting force
ground: effective control, empowerment, and seizing of a person
the way a hand directs and compels
posture: Ezekiel depicts God's action in vivid anthropomorphic terms while maintaining divine transcendence
instances.explanation: God is described as having a 'hand' that comes upon Ezekiel, a personifying and metonymic idiom for God powerfully taking hold of and empowering him.

deliberation: Most elements (storm wind, great cloud, flashing fire, radiance) are theophanic imagery but presented as literally seen in the vision. The only explicit comparative marker is 'כְּעֵין הַחַשְׁמַל', which functions as a simile describing the inner glow of the fire.

instances.english_text: and in the center of it, in the center of the fire, a gleam as of amber/chashmal.
target: the mysterious gleam at the center of the fiery theophany
visual quality of the divine manifestation
posture: Ezekiel uses an approximate comparison to convey an ineffable visual experience
instances.explanation: The inner radiance of the fire is compared to the appearance of chashmal/amber to communicate its metallic, glowing brilliance.

deliberation: The verse states that within the fire were four 'living creatures' whose 'appearance' was a human form. The use of דְּמוּת here signals visionary likeness, but functions as description of form rather than a rhetorical comparison like a simile; no explicit figurative trope beyond visionary ontology.
Simple description of the number of faces and wings on each creature; no comparative particles (כ) or idiomatic expressions. The strangeness is in content, not in figurative language.

Examined the descriptions of legs and feet. Two explicit 'כ' comparisons appear: feet 'like a calf's hoof' and their sparkle 'like burnished bronze.' Both are straightforward similes, one about shape, one about visual shine.

instances.english_text: and the feet of each were like a single calf’s hoof
target: the shape of the creatures' feet
anatomical feature of the living creatures
ground: similar contour and structure (rounded, hoof-like form)
posture: Ezekiel uses a concrete animal comparison to make the strange anatomy intelligible
instances.explanation: The unusual feet of the creatures are compared to a calf's hoof to clarify their form.

instances.english_text: and their sparkle was like the luster of burnished bronze
target: the visual gleam of the creatures' legs/feet
posture: Ezekiel appeals to familiar metallic shine to approximate an otherworldly radiance
instances.explanation: Their radiance is likened to the shine of polished bronze, highlighting brightness and reflective quality.

deliberation: States that the creatures had human hands under their wings; this is a literal description within the vision, not a comparison. No 'like/as' constructions or idiomatic anthropomorphisms beyond stating 'human hands.'

Looked for comparisons in the movement and wing contact. The phrase 'חֹבְרֹת אִשָּׁה אֶל־אֲחוֹתָהּ כַּנְפֵיהֶם' uses 'woman to her sister' of wings, which is a non-literal expression/idiom for intimate adjacency and linkage.

instances.english_text: their wings touched one another (joined, a woman to her sister)
target: the close connection of the creatures' wings
spatial relationship of parts of the creatures
vehicle: a woman joined to her sister
ground: unbroken togetherness of those naturally bound
posture: Ezekiel uses a familial idiom to express the tight linkage of the wings
evocative descriptive stance drawing on kinship imagery
instances.explanation: Wings are described with a familial idiom ('woman to her sister') to convey how closely they were joined.

deliberation: The text lists the actual faces on the creatures—human, lion, ox, eagle—without 'like' language. These are part of the creature's described anatomy in the vision, not figures comparing something else to them.
Describes wing arrangement: two wings joined to another creature, two covering the bodies. No explicit comparative particle or idiomatic phrase beyond straightforward spatial description.

Explains that the creatures went wherever the spirit would go, without turning. 'Spirit' (רוּחַ) here functions as a real animating principle in the vision, not as a metaphorical agent; no simile/metaphor markers are used.

Noted two explicit כ-comparisons in describing the fiery phenomena among the creatures: 'like burning coals of fire' and 'like the appearance of torches.' These are distinct but closely related similes clarifying the look and motion of the fire.

instances.english_text: their appearance was like burning coals of fire
target: the fiery appearance associated with the creatures
visual nature of the moving fire
ground: intense heat and glowing, ember-like incandescence
posture: Ezekiel employs common fire imagery to evoke the intensity of the vision
instances.explanation: The fiery elements are likened to burning coals to express their glowing, ember-like quality.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּמַרְאֵה הַלַּפִּדִים הִיא מִתְהַלֶּכֶת בֵּין הַחַיּוֹת
instances.english_text: like the appearance of torches, it kept moving about among the creatures
target: the motion and form of the fiery manifestation among the creatures
ground: flickering, darting movement of separate flames
mobile points of light weaving among others
posture: Ezekiel uses a second comparison to torches to stress the flickering, mobile character of the fire
instances.explanation: The fire is compared to moving torches to highlight its flickering, darting motion among the creatures.

deliberation: The verse uses the idiom 'going and returning' for rapid movement, and explicitly compares the creatures' motion to 'the appearance of lightning.' The latter is a clear simile.

instances.english_text: The creatures dashed to and fro like the appearance of lightning.
target: the speed and suddenness of the creatures' movements
kinetic behavior of the living creatures
ground: extreme swiftness and abrupt, darting motion
posture: Ezekiel appeals to lightning as the closest analogue for their rapid motion
instances.explanation: Their rapid movement is likened to lightning to stress its speed and suddenness.

deliberation: Simply notes the presence and position of a wheel on the earth beside each creature; no comparative or idiomatic figurative expressions.

Contains two clear comparisons: the wheels' appearance was 'like beryl' and their construction was 'as when a wheel is within a wheel.' Both use כְּ to mark similes describing color/gleam and structure.

instances.english_text: as for the appearance and structure of the wheels, they gleamed like beryl
target: the color and gleam of the wheels
visual quality of the wheel surfaces
posture: Ezekiel uses gemstone imagery to communicate the wheels' jewel-like radiance
instances.explanation: The wheels' gleam is compared to beryl to express their jewel-like, shining quality.

instances.english_text: their appearance and structure was as of a wheel within a wheel
target: the unusual construction of each visionary wheel
vehicle: a wheel in the midst of a wheel
ground: complex, intersecting rotational structure enabling movement in multiple directions
posture: Ezekiel uses an analogy to familiar wheel constructions to explain an unfamiliar design
instances.explanation: Their complex form is likened to a wheel set within another wheel to convey their intersecting structure.

deliberation: Describes the directional freedom of the wheels and the fact that they did not turn when moving. This is mechanical description without comparative markers or idiomatic figurative language.

Notes that the rims were high and awesome and were full of eyes all around. In the context of a visionary creature, the 'eyes' function as literal parts of the image rather than a rhetorical figure for perception or omniscience; no explicit comparison or idiom.
Reports the synchronized movement of creatures and wheels with straightforward narrative verbs; no metaphors, similes, or idioms beyond literal description within the vision.

Explains that wherever the spirit went, the creatures and wheels went, because the spirit of the living creature was in the wheels. Within Ezekiel’s visionary ontology, 'spirit' here is not a metaphor for something else but the actual animating force; no figurative comparison.

Continues the description of coordinated motion of creatures and wheels, repeating that the spirit of the living creature was in the wheels. No new comparative or idiomatic figurative language is introduced.
Describes an expanse over the heads of the creatures and explicitly compares its appearance to 'awesome ice/crystal' using כְּעֵין. This is a clear simile for visual quality.

instances.english_text: an expanse, with an awe-inspiring gleam as of crystal/ice
target: the visual appearance of the expanse above the creatures
ground: brightness, hardness, and transparent or translucent gleam
posture: Ezekiel selects a striking natural image to communicate the expanse’s terrifying clarity
instances.explanation: The expanse is compared to awe-inspiring ice/crystal to convey its gleaming, fearsome transparency.

deliberation: Describes wing positions under the expanse. The phrase 'כַּנְפֵיהֶם יְשָׁרוֹת אִשָּׁה אֶל־אֲחוֹתָהּ' again uses 'woman to her sister' of wings, mirroring the idiomatic metaphor in v. 9.

instances.english_text: their wings were spread out straight, one (a woman) toward her sister
target: the straight, confronting arrangement of the creatures' wings
vehicle: an intimately related pair of sisters facing each other
posture: Ezekiel reuses a familial idiom to portray symmetry and closeness of wings
instances.explanation: The relationship of the wings is depicted with a kinship idiom ('woman to her sister') to emphasize their close, symmetrical alignment.

deliberation: This verse contains multiple explicit sound-comparisons: the sound of the wings is 'like the sound of many waters,' 'like the sound of Shaddai,' and 'like the sound of a camp.' These are three distinct similes describing volume, majesty, and tumult.

instances.english_text: the sound of their wings was like the sound of mighty waters
target: the auditory impression of the creatures' wings in motion
posture: Ezekiel chooses a grand natural sound to convey the wings' overwhelming roar
instances.explanation: The wings’ sound is likened to roaring waters to stress its volume and continuous power.

instances.english_text: like the sound of Shaddai
target: the same overwhelming sound of the wings
ground: association with divine speech and thunder
posture: Ezekiel heightens the imagery by likening the sound to God's own voice
instances.explanation: The wings’ sound is compared to the voice of Shaddai, underlining its divine, awe-inspiring character.

instances.english_text: a tumult like the din of an army
target: the noisy tumult associated with the wings
collective sound produced by the movement
vehicle: noise of a military encampment or marching host
ground: sense of massed forces in motion
posture: Ezekiel adds martial imagery to communicate organized yet tumultuous power
instances.explanation: The noise is likened to an army camp to convey its tumultuous, many-sourced quality.

deliberation: States that a voice came from above the expanse and that when the creatures stood still, they let their wings drop. No explicit comparisons or anthropomorphic idioms beyond literal narrative of the vision.

Contains two comparison markers with כְּ/דְּמוּת: the throne was 'in appearance like sapphire' and on it was 'the likeness as the appearance of a human.' Both function as similes/likeness-language describing color/material and form.

instances.english_text: the semblance of a throne, in appearance like sapphire
target: the visual appearance of the visionary throne
posture: Ezekiel uses gemstone comparison to convey the throne’s precious, luminous quality
instances.explanation: The throne’s appearance is compared to sapphire to evoke its jewel-like brilliance and color.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעַל דְּמוּת הַכִּסֵּא דְּמוּת כְּמַרְאֵה אָדָם עָלָיו
instances.english_text: and upon the semblance of a throne, there was the semblance of a human form on top of it
target: the form of the enthroned divine figure
shape of the one seated on the throne
posture: Ezekiel cautiously states the divine figure only as a human-like semblance
instances.explanation: The enthroned divine figure is described as having a human-like appearance, expressing anthropomorphic form without identifying it as a mere human.

deliberation: Uses explicit כּ-comparisons: the upper part appears 'like chashmal' and both upper and lower parts appear like fire, with surrounding radiance. Treated 'as the appearance of chashmal' and 'as the appearance of fire' as two main similes describing color/texture and fiery nature.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֵרֶא כְּעֵין חַשְׁמַל כְּמַרְאֵה־אֵשׁ בֵּית־לָהּ סָבִיב מִמַּרְאֵה מׇתְנָיו וּלְמָעְלָה
instances.english_text: I saw a gleam as of chashmal, like the appearance of fire encased all around from what appeared as his loins and upward
target: the upper portion of the enthroned figure
appearance of the divine torso upward
vehicle: chashmal / fire encased in a frame
glowing metallic/amber-like substance and contained fire
ground: intense, contained fiery radiance with metallic glow
posture: Ezekiel layers images (metal and fire) to approximate an inexpressible radiance
instances.explanation: The upper body is compared to glowing chashmal and enclosed fire to express its fiery, metallic radiance.

instances.english_text: and from what appeared as his loins downward, I saw what looked like fire
target: the lower portion of the enthroned figure
appearance of the body from loins downward
ground: pure fiery nature—brightness, heat, consuming energy
posture: Ezekiel resorts to bare fire imagery to describe the lower half of the figure
intensely vivid but still approximating stance
instances.explanation: The lower body is simply likened to fire, emphasizing its fully fiery, blazing aspect.

deliberation: Explicitly compares the surrounding radiance to a rainbow in a rain-cloud using כְּמַרְאֵה and כֵּן. This is a simile; 'appearance of the likeness of the glory of YHWH' expresses cautious theological framing but is not itself a metaphorical comparison to another domain.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּמַרְאֵה הַקֶּשֶׁת אֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה בֶעָנָן בְּיוֹם הַגֶּשֶׁם כֵּן מַרְאֵה הַנֹּגַהּ סָבִיב
instances.english_text: Like the appearance of the bow that is in the cloud on a day of rain, so was the appearance of the surrounding radiance.
target: the radiance surrounding the divine figure
vehicle: a rainbow in a rain-cloud on a rainy day
multicolored bow of light in storm clouds
ground: arcing, multicolored, luminous display following storm
beauty and covenant-associated sign after judgment
posture: Ezekiel uses the familiar sign of the rainbow to interpret and articulate the nature of the glory’s radiance
instances.explanation: The radiance around the divine glory is compared to a rainbow in the clouds, stressing its multicolored brilliance and evoking covenantal associations.
